content: The Act is titled the "Trinity River Basin Fish and Wildlife Management Reauthorization Act of 1995". It clarifies findings related to the management of fish and wildlife in the Trinity River Basin. The Act, titled the "Trinity River Basin Fish and Wildlife Management Reauthorization Act of 1995", amends Section 1 to emphasize the importance of Trinity Basin fisheries restoration for tribal, commercial, and sport fisheries participation. The Secretary requires additional authority to implement a management program. The "Trinity River Basin Fish and Wildlife Management Reauthorization Act of 1995" aims to restore fish and wildlife populations in the Trinity River Basin to benefit ocean populations of salmon, steelhead, and other anadromous fish, ultimately supporting commercial and recreational fishing activities. Changes to management program. The Act aims to restore fish and wildlife populations in the Trinity River Basin to benefit ocean populations of salmon, steelhead, and other anadromous fish, supporting commercial and recreational fishing activities. Amendments include consulting with the Secretary of Commerce and managing fish habitats in the Klamath River. The Act is amended to include managing fish habitats in the Klamath River downstream of the Trinity River confluence and ensuring the Trinity River Fish Hatchery serves its purpose without hindering efforts to restore anadromous fish stocks. Additionally, the Act now refers to Indian tribes instead of tribe. The Act is amended to include appointing individuals from the Yurok Tribe, Karuk Tribe, commercial fishing interests, and sport fishing interests to the task force managing fish habitats in the Klamath River. The Act is amended to appoint individuals representing sport fishing interests and the timber industry to the task force managing the Klamath River. Coordination with the Klamath River Basin Fisheries Task Force and the Klamath Fishery Management Council is required for actions or management on the river. The Act is amended to appoint representatives from sport fishing and timber industries to the Trinity River Task Force. Members may be reimbursed for expenses incurred during their service. The amendments will be effective 120 days after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 5. APPROPRIATIONS. The Act is amended to extend authorization for restoration efforts in the Trinity River Basin, California until October 1, 1998. In-kind services can be accepted as payment for obligations incurred, and certain financial and audit reports are required. Not more than 20 percent of the funds allocated can be used for overhead and indirect costs, which are administrative in nature and cannot be directly charged to a project. These costs include compensation for staff, training, rent, travel, utilities, supplies, and other expenses. Inspection, design of construction projects, and environmental compliance activities are not included in these costs. The Secretary must prepare reports annually detailing expenditures under the Act, with information for public transparency. Periodic audits of fishery monitoring programs are required, with reports submitted to relevant committees. The Secretary is authorized to seek appropriations for monitoring, evaluating, and maintaining program investments in the Trinity River Basin for long-term fish and wildlife restoration goals. SEC. 6. NO RIGHTS AFFECTED. The Act does not impact any rights of Indian tribes or individuals. SEC. 7. SHORT TITLE OF 1984 ACT. The Act's short title is amended to include the preservation of rights. The Act may be cited as the 'Trinity River Basin Fish and Wildlife Management Act of 1984'.
